title: 1¬† Introduction

See Knuth (1984) for additional discussion of literate programming.

title: Discrete Math II Functions and Applications
text:
The Foundations | Logic and Proofs


Chapter 1:


Exercise 1a


Step-1Step-2Step-3Step-4Results


In this exercise, we determine whether the given statement represents a proposition.
What is a proposition?


A proposition is a statement that is known to be true or known to be false. If we don‚Äôt know if a statement is true or false, then the statement is not a proposition.


(a)
The statement is a proposition because we know that the statement is true \(T\) (as Boston is the capital of Massachusetts).


Let us summarize how the results were derived.
To determine whether a statement is a proposition, we determined whether the statement was true or false.
If we were able to derive a truth value, then the statement has to be a proposition. If we were unable to assign a truth value to the statement or the truth value was dependent on some variable, then the statement couldn‚Äôt be a proposition.


(a) Proposition, \(T\)




Exercise 1b


Step-1Step-2Step-3Step-4Results


In this exercise, we determine whether the given statement represents a proposition.
What is a proposition?


A proposition is a statement that is known to be true or known to be false. If we don‚Äôt know if a statement is true or false, then the statement is not a proposition.





The statement is a proposition because we know that the statement is false \(F\) (as Tallahassee is the capital of Florida).


Let us summarize how the results were derived.
To determine whether a statement is a proposition, we determined whether the statement was true or false.

If we were able to derive a truth value, then the statement has to be a proposition.
If we were unable to assign a truth value to the statement or the truth value was dependent on some variable, then the statement couldn‚Äôt be a proposition.



(b) Proposition, \(F\)




Exercise 1c


Step-1Step-2Step-3Step-4Results


In this exercise, we determine whether the given statement represents a proposition.
What is a proposition?


A proposition is a statement that is known to be true or known to be false. If we don‚Äôt know if a statement is true or false, then the statement is not a proposition.


(c)
The statement is a proposition because we know that the statement is true \(T\) (since 2 added to 3 is equal to 5).


Let us summarize how the results were derived.
To determine whether a statement is a proposition, we determined whether the statement was true or false.

If we were able to derive a truth value, then the statement has to be a proposition.
If we were unable to assign a truth value to the statement or the truth value was dependent on some variable, then the statement couldn‚Äôt be a proposition.



(c) Proposition, \(T\)




Exercise 1d


Step-1Step-2Step-3Step-4Results


In this exercise, we determine whether the given statement represents a proposition.
What is a proposition?


A proposition is a statement that is known to be true or known to be false. If we don‚Äôt know if a statement is true or false, then the statement is not a proposition.


(d)
The statement is a proposition because we know that the statement is false \(F\) (since 5 added to 7 is equal to 12, and thus not equal to 10).


Let us summarize how the results were derived.
To determine whether a statement is a proposition, we determined whether the statement was true or false.

If we were able to derive a truth value, then the statement has to be a proposition.
If we were unable to assign a truth value to the statement or the truth value was dependent on some variable, then the statement couldn‚Äôt be a proposition.



(d) Proposition, \(F\)




Exercise 1e


Step-1Step-2Step-3Step-4Results


In this exercise, we determine whether the given statement represents a proposition.
What is a proposition?


A proposition is a statement that is known to be true or known to be false. If we don‚Äôt know if a statement is true or false, then the statement is not a proposition.


(e)
The statement is not a proposition, because the statement could be true or could be false (but we do not know which case since \(x\) is unknown).


Let us summarize how the results were derived.
To determine whether a statement is a proposition, we determined whether the statement was true or false.

If we were able to derive a truth value, then the statement has to be a proposition.
If we were unable to assign a truth value to the statement or the truth value was dependent on some variable, then the statement couldn‚Äôt be a proposition.



(e) Not a proposition




Exercise 1f


Step-1Step-2Step-3Step-4Results


In this exercise, we determine whether the given statement represents a proposition.
What is a proposition?


A proposition is a statement that is known to be true or known to be false. If we don‚Äôt know if a statement is true or false, then the statement is not a proposition.


(f)
The statement is not a proposition, because it is not a statement that could be true or false.


Let us summarize how the results were derived.
To determine whether a statement is a proposition, we determined whether the statement was true or false.

If we were able to derive a truth value, then the statement has to be a proposition.
If we were unable to assign a truth value to the statement or the truth value was dependent on some variable, then the statement couldn‚Äôt be a proposition.



(f) Not a proposition






Chapter 2:


Exercise 2a


Step-1Step-2


PART A: This sentence is not a proposition because it is not a declarative sentence.
So it is not possible for this sentence to be true or false.


PART A: not a proposition




Exercise 2b


Step-1Step-2


PART B: This sentence is not a proposition because it is not a declarative sentence.
So it is not possible for this sentence to be true or false.


PART B: not a proposition




Exercise 2c


Step-1Step-2


PART C: This sentence is a proposition because it can either be true or false.
Its truth value is false because black flies exist everywhere.


PART C: proposition, false




Exercise 2d


Step-1Step-2


PART D: This sentence is not a proposition because the value of \(x\) is not given.
So it is not possible for this sentence to be true or false.


PART D: not a proposition




Exercise 2e


Step-1Step-2


PART E: This sentence is a proposition because it can either be true or false.
Its truth value is false because the moon is not made from green cheese.


PART E: proposition, false




Exercise 2f


Step-1Step-2


PART F: This sentence is not a proposition because the value of \(n\) is not given.
So it is not possible for this sentence to be true or false.


PART F: not a proposition






Chapter 3


Exercise 3


Step-1Step-2Step-3Step-4Results


(a)

\(\text{ Linda is younger than Sanjay. }\)

The negation of the proposition adds the word ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the sentence:

\(\text{ Linda is not younger than Sanjay. }\)

Note: This sentence is also equivalent with: Linda is older or the same age as Sanjay.


(b)

\(\text{ Mei makes more money than Isabella. }\)

The negation of the proposition adds the word ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the sentence:

\(\text{ Mei does not make more money than Isabella. }\)

Note: This sentence is also equivalent with: Mei makes less money or the same amount of money than Isabella.


(c)

\(\text{ Moshe is taller than Monica. }\)

The negation of the proposition adds the word ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the sentence:

\(\text{ Moshe is not taller than Monica. }\)

Note: This sentence is also equivalent with: Moshe is shorter or the same height as Monica.


(d)

\(\text{ Abby is richer than Ricardo. }\)

The negation of the proposition adds the word ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the sentence:

\(\text{ Abby is not richer than Ricardo. }\)

Note: This sentence is also equivalent with: Abby is poorer or equally rich to Ricardo.



(a) Linda is not younger than Sanjay.
(b) Mei does not make more money than Isabella.
(c) Moshe is not taller than Monica.
(d) Abby is not richer than Ricardo.







Chapter 4:


Exercise 4


Step-1Step-2Step-3Step-4


(a)

\(\text{ Janice has more Facebook friends than Juan. }\)

The negation of the proposition adds the word ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the sentence:

\(\text{ Janice does not have more Facebook friends than Juan. }\)

Note: This sentence is also equivalent with: Janice has less Facebook friends or the same number of Facebook friends as Juan.


(b)

\(\text{ Quincy is smarter than Venkat. }\)

The negation of the proposition adds the word ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the sentence:

\(\text{ Quincy is not smarter than Venkat. }\)

Note: This sentence is also equivalent with: Quincy is dumber or equally intelligent as Venkat.


(c)

\(\text{ Zelda drives more miles to school than Paola. }\)

The negation of the proposition adds the word ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the sentence:

\(\text{ Zelda does not drive more miles to school than Paola. }\)

Note: This sentence is also equivalent with: Zelda drives less miles or the same number of miles to school than Paola.


(d)

\(\text{ Brianna sleeps longer than Gloria. }\)

The negation of the proposition adds the word ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the sentence:

\(\text{ Brianna does not sleep longer than Gloria. }\)

Note: This sentence is also equivalent with: Brianna sleeps less or the same amount than Gloria.

Results

(a) Janice does not have more Facebook friends than Juan.
(b) Quincy is not smarter than Venkat.
(c) Zelda does not drive more miles to school than Paola.
(d) Brianna does not sleep longer than Gloria.








Chapter 5:


Exercise 5a


Step-1Step-2Step-3


DEFINITIONS
The negation of a statement states the opposite of the given statement.


SOLUTION
(a) The opposite of a statement can be obtained by adding ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the given statement. The opposite of Mei having an MP3 player is that Mei does not have an MP3 player.


(a) Mei does not have an MP3 player.




Exercise 5b


Step-1Step-2Step-3


DEFINITIONS
The negation of a statement states the opposite of the given statement.


SOLUTION
(b) The opposite of no pollution in New Jersey is that there is pollution in New Jersey.


(b) There is pollution in New Jersey.




Exercise 5c


Step-1Step-2Step-3


DEFINITIONS
The negation of a statement states the opposite of the given statement.


SOLUTION
(c) The opposite of an equality \((=)\) is a difference \(\text{(‚â†)   2+1 ‚â† 3 }\)


(c) \(2+1 ‚â† 3\)




Exercise 5d


Step-1Step-2Step-3


DEFINITIONS
The negation of a statement states the opposite of the given statement.


SOLUTION
(d) The opposite of a statement can be obtained by adding ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the given statement: The summer in Maine is not (hot and sunny).


(d) The summer in Maine is not (hot and sunny).






Chapter 6:


coming soon ‚Ä¶




Chapter 7:


Exercise 7a


Step-1Step-2Step-3


DEFINITION
The negation of a statement states the opposite of the given statement.


(a) The opposite of a statement can be obtained by adding ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the given statement
(note: adjust the sentence such that it remains proper English): - Steve does not have more than 100 GB free disk space on his laptop.


(a) Steve does not have more than 100 GB free disk space on his laptop.




Exercise 7b


Step-1Step-2Results


DEFINITION
The negation of a statement states the opposite of the given statement.


(b) The opposite of a statement can be obtained by adding ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the given statement (note: adjust the sentence such that it remains proper English): Zach does not block e-mails and texts from Jennifer.


(b) Zach does not block e-mails and texts from Jennifer.




Exercise 7c


Step-1Step-2Results


DEFINITION
The negation of a statement states the opposite of the given statement.


(c) The opposite of an equality \((=)\) is a difference \((‚â†)\)

\(\text{7 ‚ãÖ 11 ‚ãÖ 13 ‚â† 999}\)




\(\text{7 ‚ãÖ 11 ‚ãÖ 13 / 999}\)





Exercise 7d


Step-1Step-2Results


DEFINITION
The negation of a statement states the opposite of the given statement.


(d) The opposite of a statement can be obtained by adding ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the given statement (note: adjust the sentence such that it remains proper English): Diane did not ride her bicycle 100 miles on Sunday.



(d) Diane did not ride her bicycle 100 miles on Sunday.







Chapter 8:


Exercise 8a


Step-1Results


A.  Smartphone B has 288 MB RAM, which is the most out of the other two phones.



A. True





Exercise 8b


Step-1Results


B.  Either the ROM has to be greater or the resolution has to be greater. The resolution is greater in this example so it is true.



B. True





Exercise 8c


Step-1Results


C.  It is false because the resolution is larger in Smartphone A.



C. False





Exercise 8d


Step-1Results


D.  It may have more RAM and ROM, but Smartphone B‚Äôs resolution is less making the statement false.



D. False





Exercise 8e


Step-1Results


E.  It is a biconditional statement which is F - T making the statement false.



E. False







Chapter 9:


Exercise 9a


Step-1Results


a. This proposition is false because Quixote Media had less annual revenue than Acme Computer ($111 billion < $138 billion).



a. False





Exercise 9b


Step-1Results


b.  This proposition is true because both statements are true.



b. True





Exercise 9c


Step-1Results


c.¬† This proposition is true because Quixote Media had the largest net profit.
Note: Since this is an \(V\) statement, either statement being true makes the proposition true.



c.¬†True





Exercise 9d


Step-1Results


d.¬† This proposition is true because Acme Computer had the largest revenue.
Note: this is an \(‚áí\) proposition. Even though Quixote did not have the smallest net profit (hypothesis), the conclusion still holds.



d.¬†True





Exercise 9e


Step-1Results


e.  This proposition is true because in both directions the conclusions hold true.



e. True







Chapter 10


Exercise 10a


Step-1Step-2Results


Given:

p: I bought a lottery ticket this weekend.
q: I won the million-dollar jackpot.

Interpretation Symbols

\(¬¨p: \text{not p}\)
\(p ‚à® q: \text{p or q}\)
\(p ‚àß q: \text{p and q}\)
\(p ‚Üí q: \text{if p, then q}\)
\(p ‚Üî q: \text{p if and only if q}\)



SOLUTION
Determine the English sentences by replacing \(\text{p and q}\) by their given sentences in the above interpretations (and adjust the sentence to form a proper English sentence as needed):


I did not buy a lottery ticket this week.





(a) I did not buy a lottery ticket this week.





Exercise 10b


Step-1Step-2Results


Given:

p: I bought a lottery ticket this weekend.
q: I won the million-dollar jackpot.

Interpretation Symbols

\(¬¨p: \text{not p}\)
\(p ‚à® q: \text{p or q}\)
\(p ‚àß q: \text{p and q}\)
\(p ‚Üí q: \text{if p, then q}\)
\(p ‚Üî q: \text{p if and only if q}\)



SOLUTION
Determine the English sentences by replacing \(\text{p and q}\) by their given sentences in the above interpretations (and adjust the sentence to form a proper English sentence as needed):


I bought a lottery ticket this week or I won the million dollar jackpot.





(b) I bought a lottery ticket this week or I won the million-dollar jackpot.





Exercise 10c


Step-1Step-2Results


Given:

p: I bought a lottery ticket this weekend.
q: I won the million-dollar jackpot.

Interpretation Symbols

\(¬¨p: \text{not p}\)
\(p ‚à® q: \text{p or q}\)
\(p ‚àß q: \text{p and q}\)
\(p ‚Üí q: \text{if p, then q}\)
\(p ‚Üî q: \text{p if and only if q}\)



SOLUTION
Determine the English sentences by replacing \(\text{p and q}\) by their given sentences in the above interpretations (and adjust the sentence to form a proper English sentence as needed):


If I bought a lottery ticket this week, then I won the million dollar jackpot.





(c) If I bought a lottery ticket this week, then I won the million-dollar jackpot.





Exercise 10d


Step-1Step-2Results


Given:

p: I bought a lottery ticket this weekend.
q: I won the million-dollar jackpot.

Interpretation Symbols

\(¬¨p: \text{not p}\)
\(p ‚à® q: \text{p or q}\)
\(p ‚àß q: \text{p and q}\)
\(p ‚Üí q: \text{if p, then q}\)
\(p ‚Üî q: \text{p if and only if q}\)



SOLUTION
Determine the English sentences by replacing \(\text{p and q}\) by their given sentences in the above interpretations (and adjust the sentence to form a proper English sentence as needed):


I bought a lottery ticket this week and I won the million dollar jackpot.





(d) I bought a lottery ticket this week and I won the million-dollar jackpot.





Exercise 10e


Step-1Step-2Results


Given:

p: I bought a lottery ticket this weekend.
q: I won the million-dollar jackpot.

Interpretation Symbols

\(¬¨p: \text{not p}\)
\(p ‚à® q: \text{p or q}\)
\(p ‚àß q: \text{p and q}\)
\(p ‚Üí q: \text{if p, then q}\)
\(p ‚Üî q: \text{p if and only if q}\)



SOLUTION
Determine the English sentences by replacing \(\text{p and q}\) by their given sentences in the above interpretations (and adjust the sentence to form a proper English sentence as needed):


I bought a lottery ticket this week if and only if I won the million dollar jackpot.





(e) I bought a lottery ticket this week if and only if I won the million-dollar jackpot.





Exercise 10f


Step-1Step-2Results


Given:

p: I bought a lottery ticket this weekend.
q: I won the million-dollar jackpot.

Interpretation Symbols

\(¬¨p: \text{not p}\)
\(p ‚à® q: \text{p or q}\)
\(p ‚àß q: \text{p and q}\)
\(p ‚Üí q: \text{if p, then q}\)
\(p ‚Üî q: \text{p if and only if q}\)



SOLUTION
Determine the English sentences by replacing \(\text{p and q}\) by their given sentences in the above interpretations (and adjust the sentence to form a proper English sentence as needed):


If I did not buy a lottery ticket this week, then I did not win the million dollar jackpot.





(f) If I did not buy a lottery ticket this week, then I did not win the million-dollar jackpot.





Exercise 10g


Step-1Step-2Results


Given:

p: I bought a lottery ticket this weekend.
q: I won the million-dollar jackpot.

Interpretation Symbols

\(¬¨p: \text{not p}\)
\(p ‚à® q: \text{p or q}\)
\(p ‚àß q: \text{p and q}\)
\(p ‚Üí q: \text{if p, then q}\)
\(p ‚Üî q: \text{p if and only if q}\)



SOLUTION
Determine the English sentences by replacing \(\text{p and q}\) by their given sentences in the above interpretations (and adjust the sentence to form a proper English sentence as needed):


I did not buy a lottery ticket this week and I did not win the million dollar jackpot.





(g) I did not buy a lottery ticket this week and I did not win the million dollar jackpot.





Exercise 10h


Step-1Step-2Results


Given:

p: I bought a lottery ticket this weekend.
q: I won the million-dollar jackpot.

Interpretation Symbols

\(¬¨p: \text{not p}\)
\(p ‚à® q: \text{p or q}\)
\(p ‚àß q: \text{p and q}\)
\(p ‚Üí q: \text{if p, then q}\)
\(p ‚Üî q: \text{p if and only if q}\)



SOLUTION
Determine the English sentences by replacing \(\text{p and q}\) by their given sentences in the above interpretations (and adjust the sentence to form a proper English sentence as needed):


I did not buy a lottery ticket this week and I did not win the million dollar jackpot.





(h) I did not buy a lottery ticket this week or, I bought a lottery ticket this week and won the million dollar jackpot.

Chapter 5:

Exercise 5a


Step-1Step-2Step-3


DEFINITIONS
The negation of a statement states the opposite of the given statement.


SOLUTION
(a) The opposite of a statement can be obtained by adding ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the given statement. The opposite of Mei having an MP3 player is that Mei does not have an MP3 player.


(a) Mei does not have an MP3 player.




Exercise 5b


Step-1Step-2Step-3


DEFINITIONS
The negation of a statement states the opposite of the given statement.


SOLUTION
(b) The opposite of no pollution in New Jersey is that there is pollution in New Jersey.


(b) There is pollution in New Jersey.




Exercise 5c


Step-1Step-2Step-3


DEFINITIONS
The negation of a statement states the opposite of the given statement.


SOLUTION
(c) The opposite of an equality \((=)\) is a difference \(\text{(‚â†)   2+1 ‚â† 3 }\)


(c) \(2+1 ‚â† 3\)




Exercise 5d


Step-1Step-2Step-3


DEFINITIONS
The negation of a statement states the opposite of the given statement.


SOLUTION
(d) The opposite of a statement can be obtained by adding ‚Äúnot‚Äù to the given statement: The summer in Maine is not (hot and sunny).
